content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions regarding subsidy fees. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to adjust subsidy fees, with the maximum amount not exceeding 1.38 percent per year. The changes are effective until September 30, 2001. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to adjust subsidy fees, with the maximum amount not exceeding 1.38 percent per year. The amendments become effective on October 1, 2001. SEC. 3. CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. Amends Section 312 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 by removing a specific disclosure requirement. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. Amendments are made to criminal and civil penalties related to small business investment companies and the Small Business Administration. The Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989 is also amended to redesignate subsections and make changes to paragraph (1) and (2) of subsection (c). Amendments are made to the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989, including redesignating subsections and making changes to subsection (c) by adding a new paragraph (3) referencing section 16(a) of the Small Business Act. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. Amendments to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allow for the removal or suspension of management officials. SEC. 313 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines 'management official' and allows for their removal if they commit substantial violations. SEC. 313 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 defines 'management official' and allows for their removal if they commit substantial violations, including violations under this Act, regulations issued under this Act, or a final cease-and-desist order. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows for the removal of a management official who has willfully committed a substantial breach of fiduciary duty involving personal dishonesty. The notice of intention to remove must include the grounds for removal and schedule a hearing. The notice of intention to remove a management official must include grounds for removal and schedule a hearing within 30 to 60 days. The Administrator can set an earlier or later date for a hearing upon request by the management official or the Attorney General. If the management official does not appear at the hearing, they will be deemed to have consented to the issuance of an order of removal. Upon consent or establishment of grounds for removal, the Administrator may issue orders of removal from office as deemed appropriate. The Administrator may issue orders of removal from office upon consent or establishment of grounds specified in the notice of removal. Orders become effective after 30 days of service and remain enforceable. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit participation if deemed necessary for protection of the licensee or Administration's interests. If a management official is suspended or prohibited from a licensee's affairs, they can seek a stay from the United States district court. The court has jurisdiction to halt the suspension or prohibition until administrative proceedings are completed. The United States district court can grant a stay of suspension or prohibition for a management official facing administrative proceedings. If a judgment of conviction is entered against the management official, the Administrator may issue an order removing them from their position. If a judgment is entered against a management official, the Administrator can issue an order removing them from their position, which becomes effective upon service to the licensee. A finding of not guilty does not prevent the Administrator from later suspending or removing the official from office. The Administrator can still suspend or remove a management official from office even after a finding of not guilty. Notifications of such actions must also be served to the licensee. Notifications of actions taken against a management official must also be served to the interested licensee. Hearings will be held in the Federal judicial district where the licensee's principal office is located, unless otherwise agreed upon, and will follow the provisions of chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code. Orders must be issued within 90 days after the Administrator conducts a hearing. "After a hearing, the Administrator will render a decision within 90 days and issue orders consistent with the provisions of this section. The Administrator also has the authority to modify orders." The Administrator may modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section at any time, upon proper notice, unless a petition for review is filed in a court of appeals. Judicial review of an order issued under this section shall be exclusively as provided in this subsection. Upon filing a petition under subparagraph (A), the court will have exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside the Administrator's order. The court clerk will transmit the record to the Administrator as required by law. The court has exclusive jurisdiction to review and make decisions on the Administrator's order. The court's judgment is final but can be reviewed by the Supreme Court upon certiorari. The court's judgment and decree are final but can be reviewed by the Supreme Court of the United States upon certiorari. Proceedings for judicial review do not automatically stay any orders issued by the Administrator. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees: Amendment to the Small Business Act reduces guarantee fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002. The guarantee fee is 1 percent for loans up to $150,000 and 2.5 percent for loans above that amount. Assistance under loans or financings made by the Small Business Administration during this period will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. Amendments to section regarding the use of funds are also made. The amendments made to the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 starting on October 1, 2002, will be treated as separate programs for budgetary purposes. The use of funds for these amendments will be effective only if funds are made available under appropriations Acts. The amendments will become effective on October 1, 2002.
